Sorry, I wasn't clear what I meant.  When I called this "alternative 
speciation" I meant as a strategy to use entirely instead of the 
current approach.  e.g. I'm listing here other ways of splitting 
species, and in a while I'll list ways of merging them again, and 
when you have both of those there won't be need for the current 
compare and assign to put individuals into species, I'll just create 
species to address specific situations and pursue them until they 
either become productive or get fall foul of some heuristic and get trashed.

e.g. for my first take on this, I wasn't thinking of very having more 
than two species, and then only evolving one at a time, so:

1) seed mainstream...
2) evolve until it stalls
3) generate a side-species using one of the approaches I outlined
4) evolve the side-species until it stalls
5) if the side-species is fitter, it replaces the mainstream and go to 3, else
6) merge the side-species into the mainstream and go to 2

--

While comparison based speciation clearly works very well for Ken's 
original objective, I'm coming more round to the idea now that we now 
need a little more from a speciation strategy.

In particular, I'm becoming uneasy with the idea of assigning 
individuals to species based on a comparison (yes, I think I said 
this before...).  Specifically because when you do that, you are 
nudging the species closer together.  Why, consider the creation of 
an individuals who are hybrids of species X and Y.  Obviously they 
will fall into either X, or Y or Z (some other species).  In either 
case all three species have been moved a small distance closer together.

A similar argument applies when mutating individuals from a single 
species, if the individual is tested first against some species other 
than the one it came from, then the chances are the second species 
has been moved closer to the first.

You are probably saying "but how are things different if in another scheme?"

Well I'm glad you asked me that :)  If an individual is parented from 
a single species, mutated and then assigned back to the same species, 
then sure, there is a chance that will be a move closer to some other 
species, but note that this move is no more likely to be in that 
direction than in any other.  And in the case of inter-species 
breeding... I would never do that except when I had the specific 
objective of merging the two species (and a merge can always fail, if 
the result turns out not be fitter than the parent species)...

>Hmm which makes me wonder if interspecies reproduction should be
>increased between more similar species, which sort of ties in with the
>next bit...

I'm not quite sure how you got to this from the previous paragraph, 
but did you also see my previous suggestion that one should only ever 
merge from a less fit species to a fitter one.  The idea there being 
that merging from fitter to less-fit will just overwrite the 
recipient species with a copy of the fit one, but when merging from a 
less-fit species, the recipient is immune from complete take-over 
(being fitter) but may gain something if the two species have 
different strengths...

This is interesting if you think of a using a tabu as a way of 
generating a side-species...

In which case multiple-side-species might be wanted, with different 
tabus in each...

This reminds me of another form of speciation that I forgot:

--

Variable target function Speciation.

VTF is used in, for example, simulated annealing, and refers to the 
same approach that EC people often use where the fitness function 
(target function) starts "easy" and is made more challenging as you 
get closer to the objective.

In this case, however, I'd like to suggest a slightly different 
twist, based on pareto.  e.g. if your fitness function is a sum over 
N test cases (say, ~620 tic-tac-toe boards).  Then you can obviously 
construct a large number (insert factorials here) of related fitness 
function each using a subset of the N test cases.

In VTF speciation all you do is generate on of those sub-set fitness 
functions, and use that on the side-species.

Obviously you have to return to the full fitness function at some 
point, and you have the choice of:

1) after the side-species stalls, switch it back to the full fitness 
function and evolve again untill it stalls, or,
2) after the side species stalls, calculate its instantaneous full 
fitness and make a merge decision as outlined above...

--
